body: @nhne Did you test this code on a YARN cluster? If not, please do so.
@bgchun I didn't test on YARN cluster. I'll test it and let you know the result. Thanks.
@nhne Please make sure to test changes on a YARN cluster for all the wake-related PRs.

Hello, @nhne and @bgchun! I have investigated this issue.

When I modified `LoggingLinkListener` to write logs with `Level.SEVERE` on exception, I could hear it complaining like this:

```
SEVERE: Error sending message org.apache.reef.io.network.naming.serialization.NamingRegisterRequest@44d86ef8 to /127.0.0.1:12789
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: io.netty.buffer.ByteBuf.writeIntLE(I)Lio/netty/buffer/ByteBuf;
	at org.apache.reef.wake.remote.transport.netty.ChunkedReadWriteHandler.sizeAsByteArr(ChunkedReadWriteHandler.java:152)
	at org.apache.reef.wake.remote.transport.netty.ChunkedReadWriteHandler.write(ChunkedReadWriteHandler.java:128)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.invokeWrite(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:658)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.access$2000(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:32)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext$AbstractWriteTask.write(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:939)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext$WriteAndFlushTask.write(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:991)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext$AbstractWriteTask.run(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:924)
	at io.netty.util.concurrent.SingleThreadEventExecutor.runAllTasks(SingleThreadEventExecutor.java:380)
	at io.netty.channel.nio.NioEventLoop.run(NioEventLoop.java:357)
	at io.netty.util.concurrent.SingleThreadEventExecutor$2.run(SingleThreadEventExecutor.java:116)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)
```

So I added
```java
LOG.log(Level.INFO, "URL: {0}", this.getClass().getClassLoader().getResource("io/netty/buffer/ByteBuf.class"));
```
below [ChunkedReadWriteHandler.java#L149](https://github.com/apache/reef/blob/b8cecb612feaa96a86c031df0b6f6f7306f215b2/lang/java/reef-wake/wake/src/main/java/org/apache/reef/wake/remote/transport/netty/ChunkedReadWriteHandler.java#L149)

and the result was
```
INFO: URL: jar:file:/home/jangho/.hadoop/share/hadoop/hdfs/lib/netty-all-4.0.23.Final.jar!/io/netty/buffer/ByteBuf.class
```

It was loading Netty 4.0.23 jar bundled by hadoop. I think the project dependency needs some tweak.
@seojangho Thanks for taking a look. Could you change REEF to use netty 4.0.23 and run YARN tests? 4.0.23 has the fix we want. Right?
@bgchun Yes, it does. I'll post the result when it's get completed.

@bgchun https://github.com/seojangho/reef/commit/1642187be3c10755f7e3730913b0188ae0e5dc35 passes all `runyarntests.sh` tests. ([Client log (stdout, stderr)](https://gist.github.com/seojangho/8aacd55c1454c5f7cd74ea6ae43a3954))
@seojangho Thanks! Looks good.

@seojangho checked the netty version of hadoop 2.7.x. The tar ball of hadoop 2.7.x comes with netty-all-4.0.23.Final.jar. It looks like it's best to downgrade to 4.0.23.Final to avoid the complicated dependency issue.
@seojangho Thanks for investigating this issue. This's very helpful. Can you send a PR that resolves https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1879?
@bgchun Thanks for filing an issue. I'll send a PR soon.

@jangho Thank you for investigating this issue precisely! I really appreciate it.

@bgchun I'm so sorry that I missed that Netty can affect Yarn environment. I will check every tests more precisely next time.

I was actually thinking that both YARN and Mesos could implement `SchedulingConstraintBuilder.requireNodeLabel`, just differently? If there are APIs only available in YARN, we should have a `YARNSchedulingConstraintBuilder` that inherits from `SchedulingConstraintBuilder` to add them. That way, a Driver only sees the APIs they can call without error.

I didn't do an actual code review, but have one high level question. This exposes a new event, `PreemptedEvaluator`, which seems fine. However, doesn't YARN preempt via a reverse container request from RM to AM? If so, wouldn't we receive a set of preemption requests at once? A Driver might make better decisions based on the set of Evaluators preempted if it is exposed together, instead of one by one.
I have ran tests on a YARN clutser with pulling most recent master branch. It passed 36 tests successfully. I will keep testing on Yarn by commits.

@markusweimer Thank you for your comment! According to this link(https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP2/HDP-2.6.1/bk_yarn-resource-management/content/preemption.html), YARN doesn't seem to make the reverse container requests but kill containers.

My concern is, how do we want to expose preemption as general APIs? (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1872)

YARN doesnâ€™t distinguish preemptible and non-preemptible resource but Mesos does. Thus, Mesos framework should choose revocable resource or non-revocable when it submits a task to the framework. So, how do we want to expose this part to REEF?

I can imagine two different paths:
1. Set a flag that represents if the task is to be submitted to revocable resources on `EvaluatorRequest`.
Major shortcoming: It exposes a Mesos specific API.

2. Set revocable as default like YARN.
Major shortcoming: It restricts Mesosâ€™s feature and a user may not want to use revocable resources.

Can you share your ideas about this problem?
Thank you!
@motus I have addressed your review comments. Please have another look. Thanks!
I think it's better to refactor the tests in this PR.
@bgchun Either way is fine with me :) so @nhne, could you please refactor the tests?
@markusweimer Thank you for sharing your idea! I made a new PR that addresses your comments. Could you please review this?

Hi All,

Apologies for the delay! I forgot to finalize this before heading on vacation.

Now, to answer your question, @tcNickolas, this regex does differentiate between 0.15.0 and 0.15.0.0 However, it leaves the last number unchanged, and simply flips the major number and first minor number (e.g. with an input of "0.17.0", 0.16.0.0 => 0.17.0.0, 0.16.1.0 => 0.17.0.0, 0.16.0.1 => 0.17.0.1 )

@motus I like your regex here, and I think it's a simpler way to do it, but I'd rather keep the simplistic loop & replace that was there originally because it's easier to read. The more complex regex requires a bit more regular expressions skill than I think we should assume of a general reader. -- Your choice though. I'd be happy to swap for the more complex statement if you prefer the succinctness.

(rebase done, conflicts addressed; waiting for a new build.)

I have a question, though - why do we have a PR with interfaces only? Do we plan to submit a separate PR that provides the implementation? I find it a bit hard to review an abstract API without really understanding how it will work and in what context.

@motus, how do you prefer me to PR my code? I was planning to first PR all interfaces so that we can check the API and, then the code. I have no experience on this, so please advise on what would be the preferred way to go.
@scan3 , can you please close this PR until #1322 is done?

> Set a flag that represents if the task is to be submitted to revocable resources on EvaluatorRequest.
Major shortcoming: It exposes a Mesos specific API.

Couldn't this be captured as a `SchedulingConstraint`, as we discuss over in #1322?
@markusweimer I will close this PR, as it is obvious that it should be merged after #1322 is done.

@markusweimer Thank you for your comment. I think it is available. 
How about using non-revocable resources as default like existed REEF did and use revocable resources only if `SchedulingConstraint` set?
@motus COuld you please help to review it when you get time? Thanks!
@motus or @jwang98052 , can you please test this ASAP? This fixes a syntax error which prevents any of our other pull requests from succeeding.
I will test and merge

Two test failures are transit failures. Others are OK. I will merge now.
Please change Org.Apache.REEF.Wake.nuspec as well.

@jwang98052 , this is ready for another review.

P.S. I've opened a JIRA issue [REEF-1886](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1886) regarding the JVM crash in Travis and assigned it to @dougmsft

I did merged Http tests into `TransportTest` and `RemoteManagerTest` repectly.

Thanks for the review Markus. The build caught a bug with one of the tests that I am looking at and will repost those changes. It has to do with the listing the blob storage - one of the azure apis that I changed.
OK, it was a change I made with the test. This is now fixed and waiting for build results.

So both Appveyor and Travis failed, but it looks like its due to known issues:

Travis failed on openjdk due to the ProtocolBuffer overflow, issue created here:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1886

VS2017 passed

VS2015 and VS2013 failed on TestFailedMapperOnLocalRuntime, but this is a know issue:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1271

VS2013 also failed on TestGetConfigFromProtoBufClassHierarchy, but this is also a known issue:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1847

@jwang98052 I've pushed a new PR that can be merged into your branch at https://github.com/jwang98052/reef/pull/4

We can have an enum to define all supported keys by YARN. That will make it strong types. If Yarn ever add any new keys, we will need to update pour code to add it. 

Allow any key string is flexible, but also easy to make mistake such as typo error. 

Take entire map from client is one option, allow client to add key value pair from API is more convenient. Basically the question is shall we expose YARN API parameters directly to REEF client, or shall we have our own way to expose it.

Maybe we need constants for the known keys, but allow arbitrary keys to be used?

Also, we should call the `add...` methods `set...` as they really have those override semantics and not an `add` semantics.
"Maybe we need constants for the known keys, but allow arbitrary keys to be used." -- Sounds good. I will get existing keys defined in YARN.
@motus Changes have been pushed. Thanks!
@markusweimer I have addressed your review comments and pushed the change. Thanks!

@jwang98052 You're probably the best person to review this PR, as you're the most familiar with IMRU examples. It would probably be nice to add a description of parameters for BroadcastAndReduce test - I couldn't figure them out at a glance.
Thanks - I will let them know.

Ok TODO comments are updated.

AppVeyor build here:
https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/reef/build/1940-master

Looks good.
Should you give an example like .\Org.Apache.REEF.IMRU.Examples.exe true 10 8900 1000 broadcastandreduce
Also there are more training  parameters and fault tolerant parameters after it. Is this file only for basic command?

@jwang98052 I'm not sure the example will be super useful - it's just a matter of listing the right parameters in the right order?

Like I said, I couldn't figure out what these parameters do at a glance, and couldn't find full documentation for them. For example, for "dims" the documentation in `BroadcastReduceConfiguration.cs` says it's the number of dimensions but I'm not sure what kind of dimensions they are. If you know what they are, could you add those descriptions to this instruction?

You can add the following:

Additional parameters for broadcastandreduce and broadcastandreduceft methods:
6. dimension (default 10)
7. chunkSize (default 2)
8. mapperMemory (default 512)
9. updateTaskMemory (default 512)
10.iterations (default 100)

more additional parameters for broadcastandreduceft method:
11. maxRetryNumberInRecovery (default 10)
12. totalNumberOfForcedFailures (default 2). This is the number of on purposely failures. It is for tests.

That still doesn't explain what are dimension and chunk size and other parameters :-) This test assumes that the user who wants to run it already knows what broadcastandreduce job does - which is probably not true.

I actually think if someone is interested in running IMRU example, he/she should know something about IMRU and machine learning little bit. If it is purely for testing, he/she can use default values. 
Or @markusweimer may give some detail explanations.
@dougmsft, you might want to have a look at this one as it introduces asynchronous communications in the Bridge.

I'll do a test on my machine and merge.
@markusweimer I am sorry but the progress is currently suspended because the semester has begun. May I close this issue and reopen it when I am available?
@scan3 that would be great! Ideally, leave a note on the JIRA with a link to your work-in-progress branch. That way, we can't loose track of it.
@markusweimer Sure I will. Thank you for your comment!
The last commit reverts REEF-1827. Is that the intention?
Yes, at least the .AbsolutePath won't break the current client before I added fix back.
Ah, so the intent is to merge this, but keep the JIRA open and file another, more permanent fix against it later?
Yes, I think not breaking the build has a higher priority.
I don't think REEF-1827 breaks the build, but it does break tests on HDFS clusters. I will go ahead and merge this, but not close the issue.

REEF-1827 didn't break the build, it broke at run time. In our client's scenario, the file had "#N" in extension. uri.AbsolutePath somehow dropped that "#N". When the downstream still tries to use the same file name, it couldn't file the file. And the file without "#N" is in cluster.
Tests pass locally. Also, the command line builds using `dotnet` still work.
Tests pass locally, but I have not tested this on YARN.
LGTM the test failure appears to be transient. I will commit.
LGTM Sergiy and I will test it on Yarn. I am requesting access to the CISL cluster. I will commit if it passes.
@markusweimer @jwang98052 I think I've incorporated all your suggestions in the instructions. Please take another look
Local tests pass. Waiting for access to CISL cluster for YARN testing.
